segments.text: I wanted to move on to your next job.
I went into the advisory program, which was the Military Assistance Command Vietnam, or MACV.
And it was the chance to move away from American units into an American compound
But you went out and worked counterparts.
You had a Vietnamese across the desk from you, the job assignment.
You were the advisor to them.
And I think that's one of the problems some of our higher level commanders had.
You did not run the Vietnamese army.
You merely provided advice they could accept or reject.
One of the problems was you had to prove to them
Which, once again, took up time until you get to the point they're happy that you're trustworthy.
You know, every month, every six months, or every year, in walks a new American to do this job.
And as one of them remarked was, when asked, why don't you guys press the war harder?
You can fight hard as you want.
You're here for a year.
I'm here for the rest of my life.
Yeah.
You know, I've got my fixed amount of time unless I do something unusual to stay there.
I do my job, I arrive, I learn my job, I perform my job, I get nervous about leaving and I leave.
The next American walks in, usually with about a three-day overlap from you to me, and says, hi, I'm your replacement.
He says, I'm so glad to see you here.
I thought they might want to keep me.
And you take him over and you introduce him to his counterpart, your best friend after a year at least, a trustee.
And who are you?
I'm the new American here.
What's going on?
And he spends the next 30, 60, 90 days trying to find out where North is.
So we had a problem.
They had a problem.
There was also the question, I guess looking at it, that whether the best went to the advisory program or whatever.
The emphasis was big unit battles.
Big unit battles didn't win the war.
The question may have been and always remain that one,
The war was probably lost in the hamlets, the villages.
This is where the advisor lived and died.
He lived in the mud outpost.
You ate with him.
You wore the same armament or lack of armament they wore.
You didn't wear, with the Vietnamese army, you didn't wear American flag vests and steel helmets when you went on patrol.
You wore your shirt open to the sleeve, you know, sleeves up like theirs, lightly armed.
They wore tennis shoes.
You wore your boots.
You carried your chopsticks in your pocket.

What we tried to do, and I think it was the part that was successful in Vietnam, first you had to prove you were there to stay, which was a difficult thing to do, particularly when you left every year.
Beyond the individual leaving, we had to say, if you trust us, you risk your life.
My advice is this is how we fight the war.
That's not what the problem is.
Don't you understand?
And you would hang on to what the problem was.
And this was going on forever.
The time you learned your job, you were through.
It was time to go.
In other words, they tell one of the things in Vietnam, the first 30 days, you got killed because you were stupid.
The next 10 months, you did your job.
The last 30 days, you got killed because you were too cautious.
You were worried about dying.
I'm short.
I'm real short.
You counted days.
When days got too small, you switched to hours, then jumped to minutes.
And everybody that ever went could tell you how long they were there.
It's just one of these.
And depending on where you were, some units had the short timer stick, others no different symbol.
But everybody marked or counted and you knew about where you were.
And I say that it's a relative, how close am I?
You weren't safe in Vietnam until you were out of there.
That's the only safe, that was the only way you knew you lived over Vietnam was you're over international water and you're on your way home.
Till then,
than you think of Gary?
You were fair game.
I think the hardest thing we had to do and learn was we were guests of their government.
And as guests, you had to learn to conduct yourself with certain actions that you might not have done had it been your home versus their home.
If the Vietnamese said, we don't want to go on the operation until 10 o'clock in the morning, you wait until 10 o'clock, even though you knew by 10 o'clock everything's over.
So you worked on the next three weeks, four weeks, a month, trying to get them to say, look, let's do this differently.
Maybe try this, but you had to make their commander believe he thought of it.
If you walked up to me, and I'm the American, and you're the Vietnamese, and I said, do it,
He may do it because he knows your radio calls for the helicopter in case he's wounded.
But he doesn't have any authority left in front of his men.
So you make him believe he discovered this thought in the middle of the night on his own.
And he runs out the next morning and does what you whispered in his ear.
And you can't stand up and holler, well, hot dogs, he did it.
I told him and he did it.
You just stand there.
And when you get away from each other, away from them back in your own compound or with your other crew, we got it.
Now let's hope it works.
And they had to see it in their system.
And what we did to their system that hurt was we copied it after ours.
In other words, we decided instead of us learning their way, they'll learn our way.
So we made the Vietnamese military...
a replica or a model of the American Army with all its great logistical support, which they didn't have.
And then you wonder, I wonder why they can't do that.
And you face that problem.
You know, we, at least on a large scale with the advisors, we had at one time there about 20,000 at the top levels.
top number of advisors in South Vietnam, had them assigned to all the provinces.
We had within the advisory program a thing called a MAT team, a mobile advisory team, which roamed around.
vagabonds as far as where they live.
They went from job to job to job.
The unit I was on was a province team.
We had a fixed responsibility just like a state or a county line.
We worked in a particular place with the forces that were there, but we would have mobile teams come through the area, do specific problem-solving for us, do operations.
After we were successful, the Vietnamese took over.
This unit went on somewhere else and worked for the next Vietnamese unit.
Americans were with you in the province?
We had 100 assigned at the team.
100 officers and men.
Total men.
In your team?
In the intelligence business, we had four at province level.
We would have...
one or two, normally an officer and a sergeant, and each one of the subsectors are districts.
So what you really had in the intelligence business was about, in our province with Benoit, we had six districts, so you probably had at best 13, 14 people, which did not work for you.
Now listen carefully to this one.
I'm on the province team
But the other Americans are advisors to the Vietnamese at each level of their operation.
I had no team.
I had myself, my American NCO.
I was the advisor to the Vietnamese intelligence officer at the province.
I could advise him all I wanted.
If he didn't want to take it, you couldn't make him.
They went through the game, by the way.
They were very good at learning what we were good at watching.
They always wanted more typewriters, pens, pencils, chairs, goodies, because it was a status symbol.
How many things... Let's talk about, let's you and I go to the woods and collect intelligence.
Kind of exciting.
A lot of them didn't want to go to the woods.
You live longer not going to the woods.
But...

what we had and the hardest thing to learn and our commanders and i say the commanders the the province senior advisor are actually the ones we worried about the province senior advisor was a civilian the deputy was the military and always used the term the it was deputy but we just called him the boss because he was the colonel and i'm not sure that they ever really
got out at the end, understood what happened or didn't happen in the field.
If you had reports to do that said an area was safer and we had a thing called the Hess Report Hamilton Evaluation System.
One month you raise one village, you lower the other one.
Nobody spent the night out there.
The village chief didn't even spend the night out there.
But on paper, we pacified the area.
In real life, go on out there, but be sure you're back before 5 o'clock or don't worry about being back.
Don't wait on sundown.
Don't plan on eating supper and strolling down the street at midnight in these villages, not unless you took a lot of guns with you.
And we played this paper chase game.
It all looked good on paper.
But the problem was that's where the war, that's where the fighting was being done that we were doing was on paper.
And that left some problem areas and some things there.
What did a typical operation in this capacity consist of?
Well, what you had, your normal, if you were at province headquarters,
You were responsible, much like the order of battle section for the intelligence picture in the province.
Except this time, instead of having American troops who collected the data, you had Vietnamese, the national police, their army.
We had a thing at the province level called the PRU's Province Recon Unit, which worked directly for the province chief who were trained and directed by us.
In other words, you had 50 guys, you'd train, equip,
You got them M16s, legally or otherwise, American uniforms, boots, ammunition.
You trained them as a private mercenary reaction force to do what you wanted done.
When the intelligence came in, you had somebody to go.
The district chiefs is where the actual collection went on.
The National Police had a thing called the National Police Field Force.
We had an alphabet organization of collectors there.
census grievance, we had people under all kinds of names and covers out in the woods, out in the villages, trying to collect data about the other side.
What our normal job there was was to convince the Vietnamese, okay, we've got enough, or they would come to you and said, we want an operation.
Our job then was to make sure we got the helicopters, we got the assets they needed to get them out there.
Or, in some cases, they would come to us
have a lot of data, but they couldn't do it because so-and-so was kin to somebody.
The old power game.
The brother-in-law of the relative of.
And at this time, sometimes our side of the organization might mount an operation.
Just go bag him.
We know who it is.
And after you bring him in, let them explain how he got there.
He doesn't know how he got there.
Hi, who are you?
Let's go.
Midnight Hook.
We'll go get them.
Those were less rare.
What you normally had was you would go out with the Vietnamese unit, go in a village, you walk through the same village every day.
The day you walk in and grab whoever you're after.
You may have a team set in the jungle and watch them for three or four months and then grab them.
It's just, it was what level of proof do you want somebody to work for the other side?
Do you want three reports from the laundry woman that so-and-so is a communist?
Do you want him in a meeting with a communist?
It was how much proof and what level do you go get him?
Do you want him carrying a gun?
Depending on what it was, you'd go out and try to round them up.
And it depended on if the district chief wanted to make himself look good to the province chief, he ran and got one.
He also may have saved one so when things got rough and tough, he had a spare.
You see, they were there forever, too, and they were appointed by the province chief.
The district chiefs owed their job to the province chief, who owed his job to the military command.
So it was one gigantic bureaucratic thing.
You scratch my back, and I'll scratch yours.
You knife me, and I'll stab you.
And you had to learn to work your way through it.
What pleased one boss might not please the other, and be careful.
So you worked with Arvin and the National Guard?
We worked, the level we worked with, we didn't work with the Arvins at all.
The province commander had some.
We worked with what would be the National Guard units, the regional police,
The RFPF, the Regional Forced Popular Force.
This was where the war was won or lost, the village troops.
The two squads in the village, you had to learn, and finally when you were good, you went out around the villages and you stayed in different places at different times.
Not because you wanted to, but because you wanted them to see you out there.
Here's the American.
He's out here to show you you can do it, you can catch them.
And you'd go out and conduct raids for them.
We also lived normally at the district headquarters.
The MAT teams lived in the villages.
We had the ones that went out.
Normally you lived in the village in one location inside of this unless something happened and you had to move.
Can you sort of describe a typical operation in the field, something that you went on, some unique one that stands out in your mind?

I guess one that would be, I won't say unique, but it stands out as one of the different ones, is we went out, we had an intelligence problem with one of our units that no matter what we did, the other side seemed to either know we were coming, they could either stand and fight, and what bothered us was you would go out with the Vietnamese, take the hill when you got to the top, the little old ladies are waiting up there with beer and Coca-Cola iced down to sell it to you.
They could have been waiting there to kill you.
Someone was telling them, you know, they're coming.
They're going to be here at 10 o'clock or 8 o'clock or whatever time.
The one funny one that happened on that run, we went out.
We normally did not have aircraft at this level.
In other words, you didn't own any planes.
You had to call ahead for a month and say on the 10th of next month, I want five helicopters, ten helicopters for an operation.
You might or might not get them.
We went on one that when we went out, we turned into a rice paddy.
Just when they went in on final approach to flare, we saw sunlight reflecting off the water, but it was supposed to be a dry jump.
Everybody had a heavy load.
So you jump in a rice paddy full of water.
It's memorable.
Bend one leg behind you.
Bend one leg however you want to bend it.
Stick one foot in the mud and hope your head's above the water when you stand up.
And then you walk back.
You see, we would ride out.
The aircraft threw us off.
They left.
You walk home.
Security on the way home from an operation like that was fun.
They bunched up.
They all climbed in a couple of dump trucks and ride back to the compound.
No security as we'd know it.
But they said, don't worry, communist not here.
We go home, eat lunch.
And we finally found the village, the district chief
found his security problems on the Vietnamese staff.
And he plugged the problem.
But we had rules about that, and we were ordered out of the compound when he had anything he had to do.
Since you were advisors, you had to go.
If he said, you leave now, you go.
I'll call you when I want you back, then call you back.
So you were guests.
Don't forget it.
Sometimes we were pushy guests, sometimes not pushy enough, but you're still guests.
There's probably at the village level no typical thing.
It's just like going to the office to work and you decide four times this week to go out on a two-mile sweep around your town, around your village.
Take about 50 people, pick up and go.
Nine out of ten times, you see nothing.
One time you have a report that the communists are out there
You hope you're right because you've been wanting them.
You get out there at the same time and your intelligence is better than theirs and you catch a few.
Or they decide to come to town to demonstrate to the villagers you can't even protect the village and they attack your compound.
You got some of these.
We used to laugh and say both our compounds were in mortar range of each other one time.
They lived in the woods about two miles from us and they were generally out there.
But by the time you could walk out there to get them, they were gone.
You could find food on the table, still warm.
But how do you sneak out there and catch them?
Their spies were as good as... And they'd come to town and collect taxes right there.
The next morning you go downtown, whoever was there said they were in here last night, they wanted rice.
Well, that's what they usually wanted.
They wanted money.
They wanted something.
They may want a few recruits.
Everybody knew somebody in the other side.
May even have a relative on the other side.
So what we had to do, and the hard thing was, convince them to get him to quit being on the other side.
Those are the difficult things to try to get done.
So you mostly, these regional force, popular forces, mostly engaged
They engaged one, two, three, four, five VC trying to sneak in a village.
Little things.
The war is not written about.
There were no thousand man battles.
It was your six men, your ten men, your twenty men, kill their twenty men or wound them.
A big firefight, you shoot all night and the next morning you got one blood trail or you got nothing.
What did you see?
I don't know.
You never saw a thing.

were fights from villages when we got in the way of their infiltration routes that's where we put these mobile teams tried to find where they were sneaking through the woods put a mobile team right there in the middle of it with 25 30 guys block them uh they'd change routes if possible we gradually did a lot of things called rome plows we
crushed down, bulldozed out thousands and thousands and thousands of trees per mile, cleared fields of fire.
But you could, no matter what you did equipment-wise, until you convinced the villager it was their war, get off the fence, you weren't going to do anything.
At least where I looked at and was, I think we could have won the war in the villages.
I think locally we held it quite well for quite a while.
But we didn't commit our assets as a country to that.
We were out fighting the big war, which wasn't the real war at all.
The real war was in each village because South Vietnam is not a country, was not a country.
About the only thing everybody could tell you who was was Ho Chi Minh.
They could tell you, they could point to Hanoi.
You say point to Saigon, it's like turning off the magnet, point on a compass, and just letting it freewheel.
There wasn't any.
Loyalty in Vietnam was family,
in Hamlet.
We never did quite grasp that at the high level.
I think the people at the bottom in the advisory program, a lot of them saw that.
It's selling it to the people at the top.
That's the hard part.
Were you ever involved in anything like the Phoenix Project?
I worked in Phoenix in and out for the 18 months that I was in the advisory program.
Normally in Phoenix you ran, these were the people that ran the province intelligence centers, the PEOC was the province, DIOC was district.
You would have that job as an additional job.
You were assigned to the team and your job was an intelligence specialist.
You also drew jobs that you did not tell your boss you were conducting.
If they wanted to know why you were gone for three days, you just ate the cake.
You couldn't say, sir, I was doing something.

It was just, I thought I had something to do in the woods, and we sat there and waited on somebody to come, and we waited, and we waited, and we waited, and nobody came, no matter if you were there or not.
But... That was an extremely killer spot.
Well, yeah, the whole thing is,
And the whole thing really, a simple sentence about it would be, Phoenix was designed to neutralize the shadow government.
And I think the records show we probably neutralized about 17,000 of them, 18,000.
Phoenix also may have gotten out of hand.
Like anything you can't see, how do you regulate it?
The bosses never said kill.
It was always neutralized.
Ours, they use the other term, rendered militarily ineffective.
That's 30% of the targets destroyed.
Your head counted for 10, your arms counted for 10.
That's one head, both arms, that's 30%.
Don't reduce a lot of things to writing.
These were done face-to-face.
Go do orders.
Come back, tell me yes or no.
End of
End of question.
So you didn't have...
Your direct superior wasn't involved?
My superior, in many cases, never knew what Phoenix...
He knew there was a Phoenix team.
We had reports we did.
We ran the stick, the pen, and the map for him.
When I conducted operations outside the gate and everybody took their turn conducting them, I may be going to tell him, I'm going out and ambush the trail tonight.
If it looks promising, I may stay on for tomorrow.
Well, you go out there, you sit down, you let everybody know you're there, then you get up and sneak off in the dark.
Go do your Phoenix job.
It may take you two days.
You come back three days from now, and he says, why in the heck didn't you answer your radio?
I was busy.
We were sitting there watching an ambush.
I said, what happened?
Nothing.
He gives you the big weenie over it, too.
A lot of Phoenix officers got fired, bad efficiency reports.
It was a matter you had to decide early in that project, and the company wasn't going to write you a good report saying you worked for them.
It was just the Army paid us.
We worked for the Central Intelligence Agency.
either one or two levels of military bosses above us, but the ultimate guy in each province was some kind of an agent, whoever the company sent over there, Mr. Smith and Mr. Jones.
Did you receive any special training from them?
Not particularly.
Everybody that basically got in there wanted in.
They didn't draft a lot of reluctant people.
Should like to do something exciting, really wonderful, you know.
Did they approach you about it?
Well, it's kind of like some of your friends that are in said, gosh, we got something you ought to like.
It's kind of recruitment from within.
The people within that know you or knew you, somebody knew you said, hey, I understand he's down here.
Can we find something?
And if they offered you something that's more exciting than sitting at a desk or going out and
Counting troops.
You're not going to stand up and get your parade, but you can go out and do something.
Let's go what we're waiting on.
And this was one of the things that I think made it interesting.
There was some danger in it, sure.
But a lot of excitement in it.
How did they know how you were going to react in that situation?
You never knew that, but I mean, it's just saying that, well, you've done your other job somewhere else.
You've been in the woods.
We believe that, and they were always short people.
In fact, one of the problems they had was nobody wanted to go to the advisory half.
A lot of it was hard to get people over there, hard to keep them.
And if there was a guy or two that came along that wanted to go do something a little off the wall, well, leave them alone.
As long as they got done what they wanted done, they really didn't care what you did the other 30 minutes using the woods.
You did their job in 30 and you took an hour to come back at your business.
You went sightseeing for 30 minutes.
Don't be stupid.
But it was a trade.
Somebody said, we think that.
Then don't mess up because you put your name on it too.
You vouch for me.
I go out there and I'm the clown klutz.
then you get a problem.
But it was a different challenge.
It was something that I think was approached and sold somewhat, a friend, you can make a difference.
And I think most of the guys that got it believed it, at least at the start.
And I think one of the problems with any program of the type is you can't come out and explain how you're doing it.

and by not explaining it the commander said you intel types can't find you know where with both hands holding on to it you can't find it look in the mirror you know and and you bagged it there was some notoriety and there were some some guys that really caused problems in the program but uh the program i think to a large extent worked it's the problem with any of those operations of that type how do you measure success
Everybody remembers the one failure.
You know, you go out and you miss the target.
You go out and bag the guy.
You can't have a parade down Fifth Avenue for you.
You got him.
Only satisfaction you get was you know you got him.
You and the other three guys in the woods, the four guys, the five guys.
And you may not know you got him.
The boat comes by, you shoot everybody in the boat because the guy's supposed to be in the boat, and you come home.
You go back to the team house, think we got him.
You have to wait until the other side, maybe a year later, two years later, three years later.
You capture a document that says, two years ago at 2 a.m. in the morning, we lost these three guys who were shot out of the boat, and they name them.
By then, you've rotated home.
Somebody may tell you one day that was in the business later than you were, come by and say, hey, by the way, you did get him.
It's not like the infantry commander.
You get the other side, you walk out, and you have your picture made there with 8,000 of them stacked up.
We didn't want them stacked up.
I just went and got one.
Did you, these three and four-man, five-man teams, were they Vietnamese joint?
No.
We normally ran, when Phoenix worked, it ran all U.S. personnel.

other words i want you to go somewhere and do something you may have had a vietnamese security force that stayed somewhere with one of the americans the other four you detached yourselves took off went and did what you were going to do and come back normally do not work joint operations in fact most of the ones we worked weren't joint because we were doing something they weren't going to do or couldn't do or somebody might said wouldn't do but it was
Did you have any type of...
I guess you had to be completely... had no identifying... Well, you didn't sign your name Kilroy was here.
You tried to make sure you left as few clues as possible in the woods.
You were tidy.
Don't go out there and play cards and eat lunch.
If you ate, you ate their food.
I mean, you know, most of the stuff that I got in on that way were go out, wait on something, do something, come back.
Where possible, you tried to disguise it as a communist act.
And there were ways of doing that.
But give the other side credit for doing something.
They did it.
And if it turned out they did it and it was one of their own, well, I guess he was disloyal.
Let them get the credit.
Did you feel like that the Phoenix project accomplished the objectives that you were out to?
The only part any of us had there then was your local picture.
In other words, you got province-wide, corps-wide over briefings.
If you asked to, I think it accomplished an objective.
We removed enemy agents, plugged leaks.

tried to disrupt the shadow government it wasn't complete you couldn't find all of them there's a lot of people i would like to have met at least once uh i think at the the level we were working at we at least kept their government from growing it was kind of the uh well it's like fighting fire ants
You kill a mound, and another mound shows up, and you go after it, and another mound shows up, and you dose the next mound.
I think we held them in check.
The Vietnamese had to be the ones who decided.
They now felt successful enough, brave enough, bold enough then to then mount the operation and go get them.
And we got a lot of that where I was.
Because we helped equip them.
In other words, Americans helped the Vietnamese.
We got them equipment.
We got them boots.
We got them our rifles.
We made them look like us.
In other words, instead of having 25 rifles, you had one.
But you had to make them come around.
It was their war, not yours.
You were merely there as the advisor.
Then you can say, yes, we won.
When the district started doing what it should have been doing by our guess of what a war ought to be, we were then happy, yeah, we're succeeding here.
You had those.
You had the failures.
But on hold, I think where we were, we succeeded.
After I left, I was told they brought American units in and cleared an area that we didn't have the manpower to clear or the equipment.

But I'm saying it was an area that we knew was a problem area that what it amounted to was if you had a 30,000-acre preserve you can cross and nobody can see through, there's nothing we can do about it.
So we came in and bowdozed it out clean.
Once it was clear, you can look out there for three miles, four miles, nothing going on.
But that's where the heavy equipment the Americans had would come in.
The village areas, I think we helped the villagers there to help themselves.
I think that part was successful.
I think Phoenix was fairly successful even though I'm not sure in the end how you measure success.
I don't think you do it in number of targets neutralized.
I think it may be measured the best way in was what did the Vietnamese government, their people feel that they were doing.
Ours became, our advisees became more capable of doing their own war.
I think that's a success measure.
I think the villages we were in became proficient.

What we did was give them that gentle nudge and once in a while show off when you had to, but you did not want to go out and do these things because if you were ever caught doing them, you're through.
The unwritten rules of the thing are coming apart.
The adequate breach of...
They didn't realize you had absolutely no trust in them to slip out there and do this.
Oh, you didn't want... We never told the Vietnamese.
Oh, the Vietnamese never knew who did it.
No.
You see, when the Americans performed as Americans, that's what it was.
Just the job was done.
Another case of communist terrorist.
Maybe his bomb went off before he got the planet.
You didn't hang a sign on anybody's desk saying, we did it.
Let them sort it out.
They may know, but they were more polite than walk up and say, did you Americans that were missing from the compound for two days go and do something?
Because your boss is already hollering at you in front of all of them about why didn't you answer what was going on.
Well, boss, we were sitting in the woods looking at something.
We thought it was nice.
And while you guys are in the woods on vacation sitting on your butts, we're back here overworked and undermanned.
Yeah, I guess that's how it is.
And you ate it.
Did that have a negative effect on you?
Oh, yeah.
It had a negative effect on you.
On your record, too?
Yeah.
If you didn't want it cleaned or couldn't get it cleaned, how are you going to clean it?
The guy that sent you to do something didn't put it in writing.
He wasn't going to write you a report card and say thank you.
Your thanks was you got to do it.
And that was the problem with part of it.
You can't stand up and have the parade because then you've lost the effectiveness.
But if you don't have the other proof...

your boss says how come didn't you perform as well as i hoped you just stand there and say well gosh boss i guess i'm not what you expected and yeah it was uh it had some negative performance it's how to get kicked and stand there uh you mentioned a while ago that uh
Sometimes the program was taken advantage of.
In what way?
Well, if you were out doing something, nobody was really going to ask you what else might you be doing.
If I went in and I bagged whoever I went after, I picked up whatever I was sent to do.
If on the way out you picked up some spare change in your own pocket, there wasn't anybody left that was going to say he took it

there were people in there that they took advantage of it but eventually it leaks because you're no longer conducting yourself as if you've got money you've got something and usually it came out very quickly particularly when you're talking about five guys that supposedly haven't been anywhere living in the woods all of a sudden act like they're uptown that uh
Most of it, a lot of it, some of them took advantage of the time.
They simply went out to do a job that wasn't going to get done.
Instead of doing it one day and coming back, you stayed a week.
What are you going to do to them?
Fire them?
You're just out there doing a job.
You weren't watched when you did these things.
In Vietnam, the advisors weren't watched all the time unless you want to call the Vietnamese seeing you drive around being watched.
You have your jeep.
Where is it going?
Gosh, I don't know.
How long is he going to be gone?
I haven't got any idea.
When's he coming back when you see him next?
And that was the most of the goof off.
There were a few that did other things, but I'm saying that was the big one.
Some got caught picking up property that wasn't theirs.
Dumb.
It's been said that the project was used as a way for...

uh people to get revenge on one another oh if the vietnamese wanted you dead it was simple supply the information to the system the vietnamese at the province level had a committee that met they made the selections on the system-wide ones as the
Who should Phoenix go after next?
Took a vote on it.
They supposedly had hard evidence.
In other words, they had agent reports, sworn statements, police sightings that you are a commie.
If they didn't like you, just have that same policeman who's your brother-in-law swear that you're no good.
The system will then go get you.
And there was problems.
Their standards of conduct might not have been what we wanted.
But you had no way of knowing because you weren't asked when you were assigned a task why it's been assigned.
You were told the committee has voted to proceed with the operation.
If you didn't want to proceed with the operation, resign.
Do you think there was instances where the

Viet Cong or Vietnamese whoever fed you with false information so that you would select the target that they wanted neutralized I'm sure without saying I have any proof I don't have any because you never saw when you worked in the field the answer to that question it's always possible whether it's probable you know I don't probably have somewhere had no
no proof and no idea of it.
Was there, what were the prevalent operational problems that you encountered?
I mean, I'll give you an example of what I'm after.
You may have not noticed it so much when you were with MACB, but perhaps more when you were, but such things as the morale problems or drug problems or language problems?
I think the biggest problems that way in 67, if you want to go back to that one, pick up I-Corps with American units, there wasn't a drug problem as such in the field.
The troops in the field were fairly straight.
Anybody that was fool enough to shoot up out there probably came home in a body bag.
You just sat there when the firefight started and anything that was standing up went down.
The drug problem was probably in the base camps.
Too many hours of sitting on your butt doing nothing but sitting on your butt.
And when you got off work, nowhere to go and nothing to do.
And particularly, I think, the longer it went toward the end of the war, and I will say
that is reading reports and speculation afterwards was, I think, probably the worst guy.
When it became apparent you weren't going to win and let's get out, then I think the problem was who wants to be the last guy to die in Vietnam became relevant.
Not me, sir.
Where I worked, and remember, when you're talking about the intelligence people, you're talking about the hand-picked crews.
And if you say other than alcohol, drinking, that type of an abuse, and I believe alcohol is a drug, that would be the drug abuse question.
A lot of them drank.
There weren't a lot, if you're heading for the question, were there a lot of dopers?
The answer is no.
But remember, we didn't take people with an IQ of 80 either.
You know, you wanted 100 plus, 125 that you could find them.

One of the things the intelligence unit did, they had people who went through the records from the people processed in who would call you if somebody came through with a master's or a PhD, an enlisted man who didn't want to be an officer.
We always had use for another brain.
We didn't get the scum or the riffraff of America
who, instead of going to the TDC for the Texas example, enlisted for six years.
Those kind were there, I'm sure, but we didn't see them.
When I went to the woods, I was with a unit that was on operation, and there truly wasn't a drug problem.
Now, as far as morale goes, and asking that question, you know, well, anti-war, pro-war, you had all of it.
Mm-hmm.

uh there were units that i visited that had some problems motivating the troops use a nice army word for get them off their butt lieutenant and get them going but that wasn't the problem that we see portrayed later where everybody in the unit did drugs i didn't see those oh
I guess from an intelligence standpoint, I would think that the language barrier would have been a problem as far as operations.
The language barrier only becomes a problem when you're with the Vietnamese walking through a town trying to talk to people, if you want to call it civilian street talk.
Two armored units engaged on the field of combat language barrier is no problem at all.
I mean, I'm shooting at you, you're shooting at me, and one of us surrenders.
Then you encounter the problems.
But the American unit, and say something about Americans, and I think this is one of the problems that we had.
The great picture of Vietnam was this mass of battles fought in jungles and other strange, exotic things like that.
Vietnam looked as much like Texas as anywhere you go.
Open countryside, rolling hills.
We had the jungles, we had the mountains.
We had both in I-Corps.
In III Corps you had jungles and some more mountains, but it was much warmer, more tropical.
The Americans that went, they were isolated.
